courseTitle: Introduction to Molecules: Bond Polarity and Hydrocarbons

pageData.text: Learn about bonding and molecular geometry using molecular models. This investigation includes determining the polarity of bonds and molecules as well as resonance structures and building isomers of organic molecules.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 10 minutes
Activity 1: Bonding and Polarity - 20 minutes
Activity 2:  Modeling Hydrocarbons - 40 minutes
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 10 minutes
Activity 1: Bonding and Polarity - 20 minutes
Activity 2:  Modeling Hydrocarbons - 40 minutes

Digital camera or smart phone

pageData.desc: Overview: Introduction to Molecules: Bond Polarity and Hydrocarbons

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Construct three-dimensional molecular models.
Sketch three-dimensional line structures using dashed lines and wedges.
Determine whether the polarity of a molecule results in a dipole moment.
Identify resonance structures and isomers as needed.

pageData.text: Chemical bonding is a cornerstone of the central science of chemistry. One unique example of chemical bonding is the compound known as aerogel. It is also called “liquid smoke” due to its smoky blue appearance. The chemical formula for aerogel is SiO<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> and it forms via a sol-gel polymerization. Simply stated, this sol-gel polymerization process involves simple molecules reacting with other simple molecules by creating crosslinks between them to form the product. There is a great deal of empty space around these crosslinks within the compound, so much so that aerogel is 99.8% air.

This characteristic gives it some very exotic properties, such as withstanding extreme temperatures. Manufacturers have applied it to a variety of products including cosmetics, paints, wetsuits and building insulation. Aerogel also has interesting applications in the space industry, where the material’s use has grown. NASA is using aerogel in its Stardust mission to the comet Wild 2 where it will be used to collect interstellar and comet dust particles to bring home for further study. The Mars Exploration Rover was insulated with aerogel to ensure it stayed warm during its mission.

pageData.desc: A cube of aerogel on display.
pageData.altText: A cube of aerogel on display.

pageData.text: Few elements exist in nature as single atoms. Other than the noble gases, the atoms in most elements are bonded to other atoms. This is because atoms are more stable if their outer energy level is full. Electrons in the outer energy level are called valance electrons. The halogens (Group 17 in Figure 1) have seven valance electrons in their outer energy level.

pageData.desc: Figure 1. Table showing valence shell electrons of atoms
pageData.altText: Figure 1. Table showing valence shell electrons of atoms

pageData.text: Each element in group 18 has a full outer energy level. For most elements, a full outer energy level has eight electrons, or an octet. Helium and hydrogen are exceptions in that they only require two <button class='glossary-text'>valence electrons</button>.
Atoms can fill their outer energy level by transferring or sharing electrons to form either ionic or covalent compounds (Figure 2).

pageData.desc: Figure 2. Difference between ionic and covalent bonds
pageData.altText: Figure 2. Difference between ionic and covalent bonds

pageData.text: : Electron is transferred to Y, giving it an octet.: Two electrons are shared, giving both atoms a filled outer shell.

The tendency for atoms to bond ionically or covalently is determined by the difference in their <button class='glossary-text'>electronegativity</button>. Electronegativity is a dimensionless number that is a measure of an atom’s ability to attract bonding <button class='glossary-text'>valence electrons</button>. Electronegativity values show periodic trends on the periodic table, as shown in Figure 3.

Excluding the noble gases, the most electronegative element is fluorine, which is assigned a value of 4.0. All the other elements have calculated values based on that of fluorine. Across each period the electronegativity tends to increase, with the nonmetal families of nitrogen, oxygen, and fluorine having the highest values. This is because these atoms have smaller radii within which the positive nuclei exert a greater attraction for the valence electrons. The alkali metals and alkaline earth metals (the groups on the left side of the periodic table) have the lowest electronegativity because their atoms have the largest radii, within which the positive nuclei exert a smaller attraction for valence electrons. Cesium and francium, with the largest radii, have the lowest electronegativity value of 0.7.

pageData.desc: Figure 3. Periodic table of the electronegativities
pageData.altText: Figure 3. Periodic table of the electronegativities

pageData.question: Which of the following determines the type of bond that will form between two atoms?

options.text: the difference between their electronegativities
the difference between their atomic radii
their number of valence electrons
the difference between their atomic numbers
their proximity to one another prior to bonding

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The tendency for atoms to bond, either ionically or covalently, is determined by their difference in electronegativity.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes electronegativity?

options.text: a measure of an atom’s ability to attract bonding valence electrons
a term to reference an atom with a full outer energy level of electrons
the number of atoms in 1 gram of a particular element
a measure of the negative charge held by an atom’s valence electrons
a measure of the size of an atom’s radius relative to its number of electron energy levels

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Electronegativity is a dimensionless number that is a measure of an atom’s ability to attract bonding valence electrons.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Atoms can fill their outer energy level by transferring or sharing electrons to form either ionic or covalent compounds. In an ionic bond, an electron from atom X is transferred to Y, giving it an octet. In a covalent bond, two electrons are shared between atoms X and Y, giving both atoms a filled outer shell. The tendency for atoms to bond ionically or covalently is determined by the difference in their electronegativity. Electronegativity is a dimensionless number that is a measure of an atom’s ability to attract bonding valence electrons.

Electronegativity values show periodic trends on the periodic table. Across each period, electronegativity tends to increase. Atoms with smaller radii, such as oxygen or fluorine, have a smaller space within which the positive nuclei exert a greater attraction for the valence electrons. Atoms with larger radii, such as cesium and francium, have the lowest electronegativity because their atoms have the greatest space within which the positive nuclei exert a smaller attraction for valence electrons.

img.alt: Figure 2. Difference between ionic and covalent bonds
Figure 3. Periodic table of the electronegativities

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Atoms can fill their outer energy level by transferring or sharing electrons to form either ionic or covalent compounds. In an ionic bond, an electron from atom X is transferred to Y, giving it an octet. In a covalent bond, two electrons are shared between atoms X and Y, giving both atoms a filled outer shell. The tendency for atoms to bond ionically or covalently is determined by the difference in their electronegativity. Electronegativity is a dimensionless number that is a measure of an atom’s ability to attract bonding valence electrons.

Electronegativity values show periodic trends on the periodic table. Across each period, electronegativity tends to increase. Atoms with smaller radii, such as oxygen or fluorine, have a smaller space within which the positive nuclei exert a greater attraction for the valence electrons. Atoms with larger radii, such as cesium and francium, have the lowest electronegativity because their atoms have the greatest space within which the positive nuclei exert a smaller attraction for valence electrons.

img.alt: Figure 2. Difference between ionic and covalent bonds
Figure 3. Periodic table of the electronegativities

pageData.desc:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
You will start by organizing the pieces of the molecular model kit. 
In Activity 1, you will determine the bond types between given sets of atoms. Then you will determine the bond polarity for bonds in a given compounds. Next you will draw a perspective drawing with bond polarity vectors for given compounds. You will then determine the dipole moments in given compounds. Then you will determine the molecular polarity of given compounds. 
In Activity 2, you will build 3D models of basic hydrocarbons. Then you will build 3D models of straight-chain hydrocarbons. Next build 3D models of alkane, alkene, and alkyne isomers. You will also then build 3D models of cyclic hydrocarbons.
pageData.altText:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
You will start by organizing the pieces of the molecular model kit. 
In Activity 1, you will determine the bond types between given sets of atoms. Then you will determine the bond polarity for bonds in a given compounds. Next you will draw a perspective drawing with bond polarity vectors for given compounds. You will then determine the dipole moments in given compounds. Then you will determine the molecular polarity of given compounds. 
In Activity 2, you will build 3D models of basic hydrocarbons. Then you will build 3D models of straight-chain hydrocarbons. Next build 3D models of alkane, alkene, and alkyne isomers. You will also then build 3D models of cyclic hydrocarbons.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the electronegativity trend on the periodic table?

options.text: Electronegativity tends to increase across each period.
Electronegativity tends to decrease across each period.
Electronegativity tends to decrease down each group.
Electronegativity is often larger in metal versus nonmetal elements.
Electronegativity is one half the atomic number of each element.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following terms describes electrons in the outer energy level of an atom?

options.text: valence
vector
covalent
ionic
polar

assestmentData.question: Which of the following describes an ionic bond between atoms X and Y?

options.text: X transfers an electron to Y, giving Y an octet.
X shares electrons with Y some of the time, giving both atoms octets.
X shares electrons with Y most of the time, giving both atoms octets.
X has a weak attraction to Y.
X shares electrons with Y evenly, giving both atoms octets.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.

In Activity 1, you will determine the bond type for each set of atoms provided in Data Table 1. Then, you will determine the <button class='glossary-text'>electronegativity</button> difference and bond polarity for each bond within each of the compounds in Data Table 2. You will draw perspective drawings and add bond polarity vectors beside each bond for each of these compounds as well. Finally, you will decide whether each molecule exhibits a dipole moment and determine whether the molecule overall is polar or non-polar.

typeBefore.text: Chemical bonds are shared electrons between two atoms. If the atoms are different, the attraction for these shared electrons will also be different. Chemical bonds are classified as covalent or ionic. Electrons are equally shared in nonpolar <button class='glossary-text'>covalent bonds</button>, unequally shared in polar covalent bonds, and fully transferred to the more electronegative atom in <button class='glossary-text'>ionic bonds</button>.

To determine the type of bond between two atoms, first calculate the difference between their <button class='glossary-text'>electronegativity</button> values. Only the absolute difference is important.

Nonpolar Covalent: If the difference in electronegativity is < 0.4, the electrons are equally shared between the two atoms and the bond is a nonpolar covalent bond. Some examples of molecules with nonpolar covalent bonds are Cl2, H2, CH4, and CS2.

Polar Covalent: When the difference in electronegativity is between 0.4 and 1.7, there is an unequal sharing of the electrons between the two atoms. Although all electrons are constantly moving within the bonding orbital, in polar covalent bonds the electrons are more attracted to the atom with higher electronegativity and will spend more time closer to that atom. This unequal sharing creates poles of charges, thus these bonds are termed polar covalent bonds. Some examples of polar covalent molecules are NH3 and H2O.

Ionic: This type of bond occurs when there is complete transfer of the electrons between the two atoms. This occurs when the difference in electronegativity is >1.7. NaCl and MgCl2 are typical examples.

typeBefore.desc: Figure 4. Diagram of electronegativity and bond classification based on bond polarity
typeBefore.altText: Figure 4. Diagram of electronegativity and bond classification based on bond polarity

typeBefore.title: Bond Polarity
typeBefore.text: The term polar refers to the poles of partial charge. In a polar covalent bond, electrons are more attracted to the atom with greater electronegativity. This difference results in a partial negative charge on the more electronegative atom and a partial positive charge on the less electronegative atom. Consider the compound hydrochloric acid, HCl. The electronegativity difference is 0.9 (|3.0 - 2.1| = 0.9). Chlorine is more electronegative than hydrogen and therefore pulls the bonding pair closer, giving the hydrogen a partial positive charge (delta plus, δ+) and the chlorine a partial negative charge (delta minus, δ-), as shown in Figure 5.

typeBefore.desc: Figure 5. HCl with partial charges shown
typeBefore.altText: Figure 5. HCl with partial charges shown

typeBefore.text: Unequal sharing of electrons can also be represented by a vector indicating bond polarity. To show bond polarity, draw a vector from the positively charged atom and the negatively charged atom. Create a plus sign using a vertical line near the less electronegative atom. The vector arrow points toward the more electronegative atom, as in Figure 6.

typeBefore.title: Molecular Polarity
typeBefore.text: Molecular polarity is similar to bond polarity. A polar molecule has regions of partial positive and negative charge and will orient itself in an electric field. This orientation in an electric field, called a dipole moment, is caused when charges are distributed asymmetrically within the molecule. The molecular dipole moment is shown as a vector to one side of the molecule. Once again, the vector arrow points toward the more electronegative atom, as in Figure 7.

typeBefore.desc: Figure 7. HCl showing molecular dipole moment
typeBefore.altText: Figure 7. HCl showing molecular dipole moment

typeBefore.text: Molecules that demonstrate a dipole moment are characterized as polar. Molecules of hydrochloric acid are polar because the bond polarity is unbalanced.

Not all molecules containing polar covalent bonds are polar. If bond polarity is balanced, the partial positive and partial negative charges are distributed symmetrically. If the positive and negative charges are distributed symmetrically, the molecule does not orient itself in an electric field and does not demonstrate a dipole moment. Molecules that do not demonstrate a dipole moment are characterized as nonpolar.

Carbon dioxide (O = C = O) is an example of a nonpolar molecule that contains polar covalent bonds. Each C = O bond is polar covalent with an electronegativity difference of 0.89 (|2.55 - 3.44| = 0.89). However, the linear molecular geometry of carbon dioxide results in symmetrical bonds and a nonpolar molecule. Carbon dioxide does not have a dipole moment because the opposing bond polarities cancel each other out (see Figure 8).

typeBefore.desc: Figure 8. Carbon dioxide showing bond polarity
typeBefore.altText: Figure 8. Carbon dioxide showing bond polarity

typeBefore.text: It is also possible to arrange polar covalent bonds symmetrically in three-dimensional space, as in carbon tetrachloride. Once again, each C - Cl bond is a polar covalent bond; the electronegativity difference is 0.5 (|2.5 - 3.0| = 0.5). The molecular geometry of carbon tetrachloride (tetrahedral) results in three-dimensional symmetry and a nonpolar molecule. Carbon tetrachloride does not have a dipole moment because the opposing bond polarities cancel each other out (see Figure 9).

Polar molecules are always asymmetric; this can assist in identifying a molecule as polar. Polar molecules are the result of unbalanced bond polarity and therefore all polar molecules are asymmetrical in some way. If one chlorine atom in carbon tetrachloride (CCl<sub class='bodySubscript'>4</sub>) is replaced with a hydrogen atom, the molecule becomes chloroform (CHCl<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub>). The tetrahedral molecule is no longer symmetric; it is now both asymmetric and polar. This molecule has a region of partial positive charge near the hydrogen atom and a region of partial negative charge near the chlorine atoms. This configuration results in a molecular dipole moment shown by the large vector on the far right (see Figure 10).

typeBefore.desc: Figure 9. Carbon tetrachloride showing bond polarities
typeBefore.altText: Figure 9. Carbon tetrachloride showing bond polarities

typeBefore.text: The presence of lone pairs of electrons can also contribute to the polarity of a molecule. When lone pairs are present, they are regions of partial negative charge. However, not all molecules containing lone pairs are polar. The combination of molecular geometry and multiple lone pairs may result in a symmetric, nonpolar molecule.

pageData.text: Complete Data Table 1 using and to determine the type of bond that each set of atoms would exhibit if they formed a bond. For polar covalent bonds only, draw a vector between atoms showing bond polarity in the last column.
Make a perspective drawing for each molecule; add bond polarities to each bond as appropriate. Take a photograph of these drawings together on your paper.
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Determine the electronegativity difference, bond polarity, and dipole moment for each bond in the compounds in Data Table 2, as well as each molecule's overall polarity.

text: For bond polarity, draw a vector between atoms.

For dipole moment, determine whether each molecule exhibits a dipole moment and write 'yes' or 'no'. If the drawing is not clear, remake the model of the molecule to help visualize the shape and direction of the charges.
For overall polarity, determine whether each molecule is polar and write 'polar' or 'nonpolar'.

pageData.text: In Activity 2, you will model hydrocarbons. You will start by building three-dimensional models of methane and propane using the molecular modeling pieces. You will then build models of straight-chain hydrocarbons and compare their structures. You will also build isomers of alkanes, alkenes and alkynes and compare their structures. Finally, you will build and compare cyclic hydrocarbons.

typeBefore.text: Hydrocarbons are a large class of compounds that contain only hydrogen and carbon atoms. They present a unique structural and Lewis dot challenge because the compounds can be very large and do not have one central atom. Another challenge is that each carbon atom can bond to four different atoms and a molecule such as C<sub class='bodySubscript'>5</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>12</sub> can have three different structural formulas (see Figure 11). The different structural formulas are called isomers.

Scientists have devised numerous methods to represent molecules that do not contain a central atom. Each representation has certain advantages, as well as limitations. Commonly used representations include the molecular formula, the structural formula, the condensed structural formula, the skeletal model, the ball-and-stick model, and the space-filling model. The model or formula used depends on the information that is to be derived or conveyed. For example, to show how atoms are bonded together the structural formula might be used, but if geometry is a concern a ball-and-stick model might be preferable. Table 2 shows six different ways in which a pentane (C<sub class='bodySubscript'>5</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>12</sub>) molecule can be represented.

typeBefore.desc: Figure 11. Pentane structural formula, 2-methylbutane structural formula, Dimethylpropane structural formula
typeBefore.altText: Figure 11. Pentane structural formula, 2-methylbutane structural formula, Dimethylpropane structural formula

tableData.hoverText: C5H12

tableData.text: Does not indicate bonding arrangements (C<sub>5</sub>H<sub>12</sub> can represent any one of three different isomers of this molecule)
tableData.hoverText: Does not indicate bonding arrangements (C5H12 can represent any one of three different isomers of this molecule)

Five letter Cs, representing carbon atoms, are attached to one another in a row by a line between each letter. Each terminal C is attached to three letter Hs, representing hydrogen atoms, by a line to each. The three internal Cs are each attached to two other Hs by a line to each.

tableData.text: Shows the number of atoms and how they are bonded
Does not show the actual shape of the molecule

tableData.hoverText: CH3CH2CH2CH2CH3 or CH3(CH2)3CH3

tableData.text: Simpler than the structural formula; shows the number of atoms and which atoms they are bonded to
Does not show the actual bonding order

tableData.hoverText: A zig-zag shape made up of five points connected by four lines

tableData.text: Simple model that is useful for representing large organic molecules, particularly cyclic compounds
Shows the carbon framework but not the molecule’s shape; not all of the atoms and bonds are represented

tableData.hoverText: Five spheres, representing carbon atoms, are attached to one another in a row by a line between each sphere. Each terminal carbon sphere is attached to three different spheres, representing hydrogen atoms, by a line to each. The three internal carbon spheres are each attached to other two hydrogen spheres by a line to each.

tableData.text: Shows the number of atoms, bonding arrangements, and shape
Does not accurately show how the atoms bind

tableData.hoverText: Five spheres, representing carbon atoms, are attached to each other in a row. Each terminal carbon sphere is directly attached to three different spheres, representing hydrogen atoms. The three internal carbon spheres are each directly attached to two other hydrogen spheres.

tableData.text: Shows the three-dimensional shape of the molecule
The bonds are not clearly indicated; individual atoms are difficult to see in large molecules

typeBefore.title: Classes of Hydrocarbons
typeBefore.text: All hydrocarbons are composed entirely of carbon and hydrogen, yet their structures can vary greatly from one to the next. Hydrocarbons are categorized into five groups: alkanes, alkenes, alkynes, cyclic, and aromatic molecules.

typeBefore.title: Alkanes
typeBefore.text: Alkanes are saturated hydrocarbons because all carbon atoms are connected by single bonds. They have the general formula CnH2n+2. Alkanes can form straight chains or branched chains. All carbon atoms in an alkane adopt a tetrahedral geometry and can rotate freely in three-dimensional space. The figures below show different structural arrangements for butane, an alkane with the formula C4H10.

typeBefore.desc: Figure 12. Butane structural formula, Isobutane structural formula
typeBefore.altText: Figure 12. Butane structural formula, Isobutane structural formula

typeBefore.text: The first four-carbon, straight-chain molecule is normal butane, or n-butane. The second four-carbon, branched-chain molecule is isobutane (iso- meaning same or an isomer), or 2-methylpropane. Isobutane and n-butane are structural isomers: molecules that possess the same type and number of atoms but different bonding arrangements. Because of their structural differences, these molecules have different physical and chemical properties.

typeBefore.title: Alkenes
typeBefore.text: Alkenes are unsaturated hydrocarbons because they contain at least one double bond. Monounsaturated alkenes are characterized by the general formula CnH2n. The presence of double bonds results in carbon atoms that adopt a rigid trigonal planar geometry and cannot rotate freely. Because of these rigid bonds, alkenes can form stereoisomers in addition to structural isomers. Stereoisomers have the same bonding sequence, but the atoms are oriented differently in space. The diagram below shows three isomers of butene.

typeBefore.desc: Figure 13. Structural isomers of butene as structural formula
typeBefore.altText: Figure 13. Structural isomers of butene as structural formula

typeBefore.text: Because the order of its bonding arrangements is different, 1-butene is a structural isomer of cis 2-butene and trans 2-butene. However, cis 2-butene and trans 2-butene are stereoisomers, not structural isomers, because the atoms have the same bonding sequence but are oriented differently in space. When an alkene has two groups bonded to a carbon double bond on the same side, the molecule is in the cis position. When an alkene has two groups on opposite sides of the C=C bond, the molecule is in the trans position. The bonds forming the C=C bond are rigid, therefore the CH3 and H groups attached to the carbon cannot rotate to match the other carbon bond. Not all alkenes exhibit cis-trans isomerization. If one carbon of the double bond holds two identical groups, the molecule does not exhibit cis-trans isomerization.
Geometric cis-trans isomers are only one type of stereoisomer; hydrocarbons may also exhibit E/Z isomerization, chirality, and optical isomerization.

typeBefore.title: Alkynes
typeBefore.text: Alkynes are unsaturated hydrocarbons that contain at least one triple bond. The general formula for alkynes with one triple bond is CnH2n-2. Ethyne*, or acetylene* (CH≡CH), is the simplest of the alkynes and is shown in Figure 15. Acetylene is linear in shape, with rigid bonds that do not rotate freely. Alkynes adopt a linear shape and thus do not form geometric isomers but can form structural isomers.
* Ethyne is a systematic name using the suffix -yne to indicate the presence of a triple bond. In biology, ethyne is often referred to by its common name, acetylene.

typeBefore.title: Cyclic and Aromatic Hydrocarbons
typeBefore.text: In a cyclic hydrocarbon, the carbon atoms are arranged in a ring (a closed loop). The general formula for cyclic hydrocarbons is CnH2(n+2-g), where g is the number of rings. Cyclohexane, in Figure 16, is one example of a cyclic hydrocarbon and has the formula C6H12. Alkenes can also form cyclic compounds. Cyclohexene is an example of a cyclic alkene.

Aromatic hydrocarbons are a special class of cyclic hydrocarbons. A cyclic hydrocarbon is aromatic if the carbon atoms alternate between single and double bonds. Aromatic hydrocarbons are very stable and form the backbone of many hydrocarbons. Benzene (C<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>) is the simplest aromatic compound, taking the form of a planar ring consisting of three double bonds and three single bonds. The figure below shows four different ways in which a benzene molecule can be represented.

typeBefore.desc: Figure 17. Full benzene structural formula, simplified benzene molecule, simplified benzene molecule with bonds, simplified benzene molecule
typeBefore.altText: Figure 17. Full benzene structural formula, simplified benzene molecule, simplified benzene molecule with bonds, simplified benzene molecule

pageData.text: Form <button class='glossary-text'>covalent bonds</button> between a carbon and a hydrogen atom by attaching a black four-prong piece to one end of a white tube and a white one-prong piece to the other end. Throughout this activity the black pieces will represent carbon atoms and the white pieces will represent hydrogen atoms.
Bond hydrogen atoms to the three remaining prongs on the carbon atom.
This structure is a “ball-and-stick” model of the simplest hydrocarbon found in nature, a methane molecule. Figure 18 demonstrates several other ways to represent this molecule.

pageData.text: Build propane (C<sub>3</sub>H<sub>8</sub>) by bonding three carbon atoms together.
If you wish to save the model as a reference, label it propane and take a photograph.
Compare the ball-and-stick model that was constructed with the expanded structural formula. Describe the similarities and differences between the two representations in the Lab Notebook.
Disassemble the molecular model.

Construct molecular models of each straight-chain hydrocarbon in Table 3. For double and triple bonds, bend the white tubes until the required number of connections between carbon atoms has been made.

Lay the ethane, ethene, and ethyne models side by side for comparison. In Data Table 3, describe the following differences between the molecules:
  1. Molecular geometry
  2. Rotation of the bonds (i.e., can the carbon-carbon bonds rotate freely, or are they rigid?)
  3. Bond strength (Which molecule has the strongest bonds?)

tableData.hoverText: CnH2n+2
Two letter Cs, representing carbon atoms, are attached to one another horizontally by a line. Each C is attached to three different letter Hs, representing hydrogen atoms, by lines to each.
CnH2n
Two letter Cs, representing carbon atoms, are attached horizontally to one another by two stacked lines. Each C is attached to two different letter Hs, representing hydrogen atoms, by a line to each.
C2H2
Two letter Cs, representing carbon atoms, are attached  to one another horizontally by three stacked lines. Each C is attached to one letter H, representing hydrogen atoms, by a line to each.

pageData.text: If you wish to save the models as a reference, label them and take a photograph.
Disassemble the molecular models.
Construct molecular models of both n-butane and isobutene using the structural models in Figure 12 as a guide.

typeBefore.text: Isomers are molecules that have the same type and number of atoms but different bonding arrangements (structural isomers) or different orientations in space (geometric isomers).

pageData.desc: Figure 12. Butane structural formula, Isobutane structural formula
pageData.altText: Figure 12. Butane structural formula, Isobutane structural formula

Disassemble the molecular models.
Construct molecular models of each of the three isomers of the alkene C<sub class='bodySubscript'>4</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>8</sub> using the structural models in Figure 13 as a guide.

pageData.desc: Figure 13. Structural isomers of butene as structural formula
pageData.altText: Figure 13. Structural isomers of butene as structural formula

pageData.text: Compare the molecular models in the Lab Notebook.
Label and photograph each model.
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: On your own sheet of paper, draw the structural models of all of the isomers of the alkyne C<sub class='bodySubscript'>4</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>. Remember that alkynes contain at least one C≡C bond.

Determine which structures are the same, and then eliminate the duplicates. Using the model set, build all the isomers of C<sub class='bodySubscript'>4</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub> using the structural models as reference.
Label and photograph the models.
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Compare the similarities between these models and the modeled alkanes or alkenes.
Disassemble the molecular models.

pages.title: Straight-Chained Hydrocarbons
pages.pageTitle:
D
 Cyclic and Acyclic Compounds (4 steps)

pageData.text: Construct a molecular model of cyclohexane and hexane using the structural models in Figure 20 as a guide.

pageData.desc: Figure 20. Cyclohexane structural formula, Hexane structural formula
pageData.altText: Figure 20. Cyclohexane structural formula, Hexane structural formula

pageData.text: Compare the structure of cyclohexane with the structure of hexane. Which arrangement is more stable?
Label and photograph each model.
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Disassemble the molecular models.
Using the model set, build two benzene molecules using the structural model in Figure 21 as a guide.
Compare the two benzene models. Are these molecules isomers? Rotate both molecules and determine whether they are the same.
Label the models as benzene and photograph them together.
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Use the two benzene models for the next activity.

pageData.desc: Figure 21. Benzene structural formula
pageData.altText: Figure 21. Benzene structural formula

pageData.text: Using the model sets from the previous activity, create the following three dichlorobenzene isomers: ortho, meta, and para.
Make one additional benzene ring.

On each benzene ring, replace the hydrogen atoms with a light green one-pronged atom to
represent a chlorine atom (see Figure 22).

pageData.desc:

pageData.text: Compare the three dichlorobenzene models. Are these molecules isomers? Rotate both molecules and determine whether they are the same.
Label each model with the correct name and photograph the models together.
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Can any other isomers be made with a benzene ring and two chlorine atoms?
Disassemble the molecular models.
Return molecular model parts to the resealable bag for storage.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

pageData.altText: Periodic Table of the Elements

pageData.content: Figure 1. Valence shell electrons of atoms
pageData.altText: Figure 1. Table showing valence shell electrons of atoms
Figure 2. Difference between ionic and covalent bonds
Figure 3. Periodic table of the electronegativities

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
You will start by organizing the pieces of the molecular model kit. 
In Activity 1, you will determine the bond types between given sets of atoms. Then you will determine the bond polarity for bonds in a given compounds. Next you will draw a perspective drawing with bond polarity vectors for given compounds. You will then determine the dipole moments in given compounds. Then you will determine the molecular polarity of given compounds. 
In Activity 2, you will build 3D models of basic hydrocarbons. Then you will build 3D models of straight-chain hydrocarbons. Next build 3D models of alkane, alkene, and alkyne isomers. You will also then build 3D models of cyclic hydrocarbons.
Figure 4. Diagram of electronegativity and bond classification based on bond polarity

tableData.hoverText: Structural formula: Five letter Cs, representing carbon atoms, are attached to one another in a row by a line between each letter.

tableData.text: Does not indicate bonding arrangements (C<sub>5</sub>H<sub>12</sub> can represent any one of three different isomers of this molecule)
tableData.hoverText: Does not indicate bonding arrangements (C5H12 can represent any one of three different isomers of this molecule)

tableData.text: Shows the number of atoms and how they are bonded
Does not show the actual shape of the molecule
Simpler than the structural formula; shows the number of atoms and which atoms they are bonded to
Does not show the actual bonding order
Simple model that is useful for representing large organic molecules, particularly cyclic compounds
Shows the carbon framework but not the molecule’s shape; not all of the atoms and bonds are represented
Shows the number of atoms, bonding arrangements, and shape
Does not accurately show how the atoms bind
Shows the three-dimensional shape of the molecule
The bonds are not clearly indicated; individual atoms are difficult to see in large molecules

pageData.content: Table 3. General, molecular and structural formulas for hydrocarbon classes
pageData.title: Table 3.

tableData.hoverText: CnH2n+2
C2H6
Two letter Cs, representing carbon atoms, are attached to one another horizontally by a line. Each C is attached to three different letter Hs, representing hydrogen atoms, by lines to each.
CnH2n
C2H4
Two letter Cs, representing carbon atoms, are attached horizontally to one another by two stacked lines. Each C is attached to two different letter Hs, representing hydrogen atoms, by a line to each.
CnH2n-2
C2H2
Two letter Cs, representing carbon atoms, are attached  to one another horizontally by three stacked lines. Each C is attached to one letter H, representing hydrogen atoms, by a line to each.

data.title: Electronegativity
data.content: a dimensionless number that is a measure of an atom’s ability to attract bonding valence electrons

data.title: Covalent bond
data.content: a chemical bond in which there is a sharing of an electron pair between two atoms, giving both atoms a filled outer shell

data.title: Ionic bond
data.content: a chemical bond formed when one atom, typically a non-metal atom, gives up one or more electrons to another atom, typically a metal atom, resulting in ions with filled outer shells for both the metal and non-metal atoms

data.title: Valence electrons
data.content: electrons in the outer energy level
